title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement [INSERT CONTACT METHOD]. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.0, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/0/ code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https:// www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

code: @Manual{,   title = {ggcheck: Inspect 'ggplot2' Plots for Automated Grading in Learning Exercises},   author = {Garrick Aden-Buie and Garrett Grolemund and Nischal Shrestha},   year = {2022},   note = {R package version 0.0.2},   url = {https://github.com/rstudio/ggcheck}, }

what: Inspect ggplot2 Plots for Automated Grading in Learning Exercises
title: Inspect ggplot2 Plots for Automated Grading in Learning Exercises
text: ggcheck provides functions inspect ggplot2 objects make easier teachers check student plots meet expectations. Designed primarily automated grading via gradethis interactive learnr tutorials.

title: Inspect ggplot2 Plots for Automated Grading in Learning Exercises
text: can install ggcheck GitHub :
code: # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("rstudio/ggcheck")

title: Inspect ggplot2 Plots for Automated Grading in Learning Exercises
text: primary goal ggcheck help tutorial authors inspect test properties ggplot2 plots. examples demonstrate ggcheck can used general; information using gradethis learnr tutorials, please see gradethis package documentation. Suppose exercise asks students create following plot engine displacement vs highway miles per gallon ratings.  can use ggcheck test students used geom_point() geom_point() geom_smooth() used exactly geom_point() geom_smooth() used order. Similarly, can test linear model used smoothing method confidence interval displayed: ’s lot ggcheck can . Read full function listing.
code: library(ggplot2)  p <-   ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +   geom_point(mapping = aes(color = class)) +   geom_smooth(se = FALSE, method = "lm")  p #> `geom_smooth()` using formula 'y ~ x' library(ggcheck)  uses_geoms(p, "point", exact = FALSE) #> [1] TRUE uses_geoms(p, c("point", "smooth"), exact = FALSE) #> [1] TRUE uses_geoms(p, c("point", "smooth"), exact = TRUE) #> [1] TRUE uses_geom_param(p, "smooth", list(se = FALSE, method = "lm")) #>     se method  #>   TRUE   TRUE

title: Inspect ggplot2 Plots for Automated Grading in Learning Exercises
text: Please note tblcheck project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project, agree abide terms.

title: Placeholders for default values — default_label
text: functions generate placeholder values. default_label() can used named argument uses_labels() check label matches result get_default_labels() name. default_param() can used named argument uses_geom_params() check parameter matched result get_default_params() name.

title: Placeholders for default values — default_label
code: default_label()  default_param()

title: Placeholders for default values — default_label
text: placeholder value used within uses_labels()uses_geom_params().

title: Placeholders for default values — default_label
code: require(ggplot2) #> Loading required package: ggplot2  p <- ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy, color = trans)) +   geom_smooth(se = FALSE) +   labs(title = "My plot", x = "Weight", y = "MPG")  uses_labels(p, x = default_label(), color = default_label()) #>     x color  #> FALSE  TRUE   uses_geom_params(p, "smooth", size = default_param(), se = default_param()) #>  size    se  #>  TRUE FALSE

what: Which coordinate system does a plot use? — get_coordinate_system
title: Which coordinate system does a plot use? — get_coordinate_system
text: coordinate system plot use?

title: Which coordinate system does a plot use? — get_coordinate_system
code: get_coordinate_system(p)

title: Which coordinate system does a plot use? — get_coordinate_system
text: p ggplot2 object

title: Which coordinate system does a plot use? — get_coordinate_system
text: character string corresponds suffix ggplot2 coord_ function, e.g. "cartesian".

title: Which coordinate system does a plot use? — get_coordinate_system
code: require(ggplot2) p <- ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +   geom_point(mapping = aes(color = class)) +   geom_smooth() +   coord_polar() get_coordinate_system(p) #> [1] "polar"

what: Get the data set used by a plot or layer — get_data
title: Get the data set used by a plot or layer — get_data
text: get_data returns data set used ggplot object single layer extracted object get_geom_layer.

title: Get the data set used by a plot or layer — get_data
code: get_data(p, local_only = FALSE)

title: Get the data set used by a plot or layer — get_data
text: p ggplot object layer extracted ggplot object get_geom_layer. local_only TRUE FALSE. get_data onbly return data defined locally layer?

title: Get the data set used by a plot or layer — get_data
text: data frame. data set found, get_data returns NULL

title: Get the data set used by a plot or layer — get_data
text: passed ggplot object (.e. plot), get_data return data set globally ggplot. passed single layer plot, behavior get_data depend local_only argument passed .... local_only = TRUE, get_data return data set, , defined locally function created layer. local_only = FALSE, get_data return data used layer, whether data defined globally ggplot locally.

title: Get the data set used by a plot or layer — get_data
code: require(ggplot2) d2 <- head(mpg) p <- ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +   geom_point(data = d2, color = "red") +   geom_point() get_data(p) #> # A tibble: 234 × 11 #>    manufacturer model      displ  year   cyl trans drv     cty   hwy fl    #>    <chr>        <chr>      <dbl> <int> <int> <chr> <chr> <int> <int> <chr> #>  1 audi         a4           1.8  1999     4 auto… f        18    29 p     #>  2 audi         a4           1.8  1999     4 manu… f        21    29 p     #>  3 audi         a4           2    2008     4 manu… f        20    31 p     #>  4 audi         a4           2    2008     4 auto… f        21    30 p     #>  5 audi         a4           2.8  1999     6 auto… f        16    26 p     #>  6 audi         a4           2.8  1999     6 manu… f        18    26 p     #>  7 audi         a4           3.1  2008     6 auto… f        18    27 p     #>  8 audi         a4 quattro   1.8  1999     4 manu… 4        18    26 p     #>  9 audi         a4 quattro   1.8  1999     4 auto… 4        16    25 p     #> 10 audi         a4 quattro   2    2008     4 manu… 4        20    28 p     #> # … with 224 more rows, and 1 more variable: class <chr> get_data(get_geom_layer(p, i = 1)) #> # A tibble: 6 × 11 #>   manufacturer model displ  year   cyl trans drv     cty   hwy fl    class #>   <chr>        <chr> <dbl> <int> <int> <chr> <chr> <int> <int> <chr> <chr> #> 1 audi         a4      1.8  1999     4 auto… f        18    29 p     comp… #> 2 audi         a4      1.8  1999     4 manu… f        21    29 p     comp… #> 3 audi         a4      2    2008     4 manu… f        20    31 p     comp… #> 4 audi         a4      2    2008     4 auto… f        21    30 p     comp… #> 5 audi         a4      2.8  1999     6 auto… f        16    26 p     comp… #> 6 audi         a4      2.8  1999     6 manu… f        18    26 p     comp…

what: What is the default label for a plot aesthetic? — get_default_labels
title: What is the default label for a plot aesthetic? — get_default_labels
text: default label plot aesthetic?

title: What is the default label for a plot aesthetic? — get_default_labels
code: get_default_labels(p, aes = NULL)

title: What is the default label for a plot aesthetic? — get_default_labels
text: p ggplot object aes aes character vector, returns default labels (based plot p) correspond included aesthetics. Defaults NULL, returns default values labels.

title: What is the default label for a plot aesthetic? — get_default_labels
text: named list element character string NULL. Strings returned aesthetics default value. NULL returned aesthetics exist plot, non-aesthetic labels default value, like title.

title: What is the default label for a plot aesthetic? — get_default_labels
code: require(ggplot2)  p <- ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +   geom_point(mapping = aes(color = class, shape = drv)) +   geom_smooth() +   labs(title = "My plot", x = "Weight", y = "MPG", color = NULL)  # Returns the label the ggplot would create by default for an aesthetic get_default_labels(p, "x") #> $x #> [1] "displ" #>  get_default_labels(p, c("x", "y")) #> $x #> [1] "displ" #>  #> $y #> [1] "hwy" #>  get_default_labels(p) #> $x #> [1] "displ" #>  #> $y #> [1] "hwy" #>  #> $colour #> [1] "class" #>  #> $title #> NULL #>  #> $shape #> [1] "drv" #>   # If an aesthetic does not exist, returns NULL get_default_labels(p, "size") #> $size #> NULL #>   # Non-aesthetic labels have no default value, so they also return NULL get_default_labels(p, "title") #> $title #> NULL #>  get_default_labels(p, "comment") #> $comment #> NULL #>   # The colo(u)r aesthetic can be matched with or without a u get_default_labels(p, "color") #> $color #> [1] "class" #>  get_default_labels(p, "colour") #> $colour #> [1] "class" #>

what: What are the default parameters for a plot layer? — get_default_params
title: What are the default parameters for a plot layer? — get_default_params
text: default parameters plot layer?

title: What are the default parameters for a plot layer? — get_default_params
code: get_default_params(p, geom, params = NULL, i = NULL)

title: What are the default parameters for a plot layer? — get_default_params
text: p ggplot object geom character string found suffix ggplot2 geom function, e.g. "point". params character vector. get_default_params() returns default parameter value name matching string params. params NULL (default), default values parameters returned. numerical index, e.g. 1.

title: What are the default parameters for a plot layer? — get_default_params
text: named list length params, , params NULL, named list default values parameters geom.

title: What are the default parameters for a plot layer? — get_default_params
code: require(ggplot2)  p <- ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +   geom_smooth(aes(color = class))  # Returns the parameters the ggplot would use by default for a layer get_default_params(p, "smooth", "linetype") #> $linetype #> [1] 1 #>  get_default_params(p, "smooth", c("se", "level")) #> $se #> [1] TRUE #>  #> $level #> [1] 0.95 #>  get_default_params(p, "smooth") #> $colour #> [1] "#3366FF" #>  #> $fill #> [1] "grey60" #>  #> $size #> [1] 1 #>  #> $linetype #> [1] 1 #>  #> $weight #> [1] 1 #>  #> $alpha #> [1] 0.4 #>  #> $na.rm #> [1] FALSE #>  #> $orientation #> [1] NA #>  #> $se #> [1] TRUE #>  #> $method #> NULL #>  #> $formula #> NULL #>  #> $n #> [1] 80 #>  #> $fullrange #> [1] FALSE #>  #> $level #> [1] 0.95 #>  #> $method.args #> list() #>  #> $span #> [1] 0.75 #>   # If a parameter does not exist, returns NULL get_default_params(p, "smooth", "shape") #> $shape #> NULL #>   # The colo(u)r aesthetic can be matched with or without a u get_default_params(p, "smooth", "color") #> $color #> [1] "#3366FF" #>  get_default_params(p, "smooth", "colour") #> $colour #> [1] "#3366FF" #>

what: Isolate a geom layer from a plot — get_geom_layer
title: Isolate a geom layer from a plot — get_geom_layer
text: get_geom_layer returns geom layer plot along global data sets aesthetic mappings layer may inherit .

title: Isolate a geom layer from a plot — get_geom_layer
code: get_geom_layer(p, geom = NULL, i = NULL)

title: Isolate a geom layer from a plot — get_geom_layer
text: p ggplot object geom character string found suffix ggplot2 geom function, e.g. "point". numerical index, e.g. 1.

title: Isolate a geom layer from a plot — get_geom_layer
text: object class layer_to_check manipulated ggcheck functions.

title: Isolate a geom layer from a plot — get_geom_layer
text: Users can specify layer one 3 ways: order appearance . first layer appear plot (one drawn first, bottom) corresponds = 1. type geom geom. get_geom_layer return first layer uses geom. combination geom . get_geom_layer return ith layer uses geom.

title: Isolate a geom layer from a plot — get_geom_layer
code: require(ggplot2) p <- ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +   geom_point(color = "red") +   geom_point(mapping = aes(color = class)) +   geom_smooth(se = FALSE)  get_geom_layer(p, i = 1) #> $layer #> geom_point: na.rm = FALSE #> stat_identity: na.rm = FALSE #> position_identity  #>  #> $global_data #> # A tibble: 234 × 11 #>    manufacturer model      displ  year   cyl trans drv     cty   hwy fl    #>    <chr>        <chr>      <dbl> <int> <int> <chr> <chr> <int> <int> <chr> #>  1 audi         a4           1.8  1999     4 auto… f        18    29 p     #>  2 audi         a4           1.8  1999     4 manu… f        21    29 p     #>  3 audi         a4           2    2008     4 manu… f        20    31 p     #>  4 audi         a4           2    2008     4 auto… f        21    30 p     #>  5 audi         a4           2.8  1999     6 auto… f        16    26 p     #>  6 audi         a4           2.8  1999     6 manu… f        18    26 p     #>  7 audi         a4           3.1  2008     6 auto… f        18    27 p     #>  8 audi         a4 quattro   1.8  1999     4 manu… 4        18    26 p     #>  9 audi         a4 quattro   1.8  1999     4 auto… 4        16    25 p     #> 10 audi         a4 quattro   2    2008     4 manu… 4        20    28 p     #> # … with 224 more rows, and 1 more variable: class <chr> #>  #> $global_mapping #> Aesthetic mapping:  #> * `x` -> `displ` #> * `y` -> `hwy` #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "layer_to_check" get_geom_layer(p, geom = "smooth") #> $layer #> geom_smooth: na.rm = FALSE, orientation = NA, se = FALSE #> stat_smooth: na.rm = FALSE, orientation = NA, se = FALSE #> position_identity  #>  #> $global_data #> # A tibble: 234 × 11 #>    manufacturer model      displ  year   cyl trans drv     cty   hwy fl    #>    <chr>        <chr>      <dbl> <int> <int> <chr> <chr> <int> <int> <chr> #>  1 audi         a4           1.8  1999     4 auto… f        18    29 p     #>  2 audi         a4           1.8  1999     4 manu… f        21    29 p     #>  3 audi         a4           2    2008     4 manu… f        20    31 p     #>  4 audi         a4           2    2008     4 auto… f        21    30 p     #>  5 audi         a4           2.8  1999     6 auto… f        16    26 p     #>  6 audi         a4           2.8  1999     6 manu… f        18    26 p     #>  7 audi         a4           3.1  2008     6 auto… f        18    27 p     #>  8 audi         a4 quattro   1.8  1999     4 manu… 4        18    26 p     #>  9 audi         a4 quattro   1.8  1999     4 auto… 4        16    25 p     #> 10 audi         a4 quattro   2    2008     4 manu… 4        20    28 p     #> # … with 224 more rows, and 1 more variable: class <chr> #>  #> $global_mapping #> Aesthetic mapping:  #> * `x` -> `displ` #> * `y` -> `hwy` #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "layer_to_check" get_geom_layer(p, geom = "point", i = 2) #> $layer #> mapping: colour = ~class  #> geom_point: na.rm = FALSE #> stat_identity: na.rm = FALSE #> position_identity  #>  #> $global_data #> # A tibble: 234 × 11 #>    manufacturer model      displ  year   cyl trans drv     cty   hwy fl    #>    <chr>        <chr>      <dbl> <int> <int> <chr> <chr> <int> <int> <chr> #>  1 audi         a4           1.8  1999     4 auto… f        18    29 p     #>  2 audi         a4           1.8  1999     4 manu… f        21    29 p     #>  3 audi         a4           2    2008     4 manu… f        20    31 p     #>  4 audi         a4           2    2008     4 auto… f        21    30 p     #>  5 audi         a4           2.8  1999     6 auto… f        16    26 p     #>  6 audi         a4           2.8  1999     6 manu… f        18    26 p     #>  7 audi         a4           3.1  2008     6 auto… f        18    27 p     #>  8 audi         a4 quattro   1.8  1999     4 manu… 4        18    26 p     #>  9 audi         a4 quattro   1.8  1999     4 auto… 4        16    25 p     #> 10 audi         a4 quattro   2    2008     4 manu… 4        20    28 p     #> # … with 224 more rows, and 1 more variable: class <chr> #>  #> $global_mapping #> Aesthetic mapping:  #> * `x` -> `displ` #> * `y` -> `hwy` #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "layer_to_check"

what: List the geoms used by a plot — get_geoms
title: List the geoms used by a plot — get_geoms
text: get_geoms returns vector geom names, written character strings, describes geoms order used plot.

title: List the geoms used by a plot — get_geoms
code: get_geoms(p)

title: List the geoms used by a plot — get_geoms
text: p ggplot object

title: List the geoms used by a plot — get_geoms
text: vector character strings. element corresponds suffix ggplot2 geom_ function, e.g. c("point", "line", "smooth").

title: List the geoms used by a plot — get_geoms
code: require(ggplot2) p <- ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +   geom_point(mapping = aes(color = class)) +   geom_smooth() get_geoms(p) #> [1] "point"  "smooth"

what: List the geom and stat combination used by all layers of a plot. — get_geoms_stats
title: List the geom and stat combination used by all layers of a plot. — get_geoms_stats
text: List geom stat combination used layers plot.

title: List the geom and stat combination used by all layers of a plot. — get_geoms_stats
code: get_geoms_stats(p)

title: List the geom and stat combination used by all layers of a plot. — get_geoms_stats
text: p ggplot object

title: List the geom and stat combination used by all layers of a plot. — get_geoms_stats
text: list lists GEOM STAT character. e.g. list(list(GEOM = "point", STAT = "identity"))

title: List the geom and stat combination used by all layers of a plot. — get_geoms_stats
code: require(ggplot2) p <- ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +   geom_point(mapping = aes(color = class)) +   geom_smooth() get_geoms_stats(p) #> [[1]] #> $GEOM #> [1] "point" #>  #> $STAT #> [1] "identity" #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "GEOM_STAT" #>  #> [[2]] #> $GEOM #> [1] "smooth" #>  #> $STAT #> [1] "smooth" #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "GEOM_STAT" #>

what: List the labels used by a plot — get_labels

title: List the labels used by a plot — get_labels
code: get_labels(p, aes = NULL)

title: List the labels used by a plot — get_labels
text: p ggplot object aes aes character vector, returns labels corresponding included aesthetics. Defaults NULL, returns labels.

title: List the labels used by a plot — get_labels
text: named list character strings.

title: List the labels used by a plot — get_labels
text: Note get_labels() return NULL label explicitly set NULL requested aesthetic present plot.

title: List the labels used by a plot — get_labels
code: require(ggplot2)  p <- ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +   geom_point(mapping = aes(color = class)) +   geom_smooth() +   labs(x = "Weight", y = "MPG", color = NULL)  get_labels(p) #> $x #> [1] "Weight" #>  #> $y #> [1] "MPG" #>  #> $colour #> NULL #>  get_labels(p, c("x", "y")) #> $x #> [1] "Weight" #>  #> $y #> [1] "MPG" #>   # The colo(u)r aesthetic can be matched with or without a u get_labels(p, "color") #> $color #> NULL #>  get_labels(p, "colour") #> $colour #> NULL #>

what: Get aesthetic mappings from a layer or plot — get_mappings
title: Get aesthetic mappings from a layer or plot — get_mappings
text: get_mappings returns mappings used ggplot object single layer extracted object get_geom_layer get_stat_layer.

title: Get aesthetic mappings from a layer or plot — get_mappings
code: get_mappings(p, local_only = FALSE)

title: Get aesthetic mappings from a layer or plot — get_mappings
text: p ggplot object layer extracted ggplot object get_geom_layer get_stat_layer. local_only TRUE FALSE. get_mappings return mappings defined locally layer. effect p ggplot object.

title: Get aesthetic mappings from a layer or plot — get_mappings
text: list class uneval, returned aesComponents list either quosures constants.

title: Get aesthetic mappings from a layer or plot — get_mappings
text: passed ggplot object (.e. plot), get_mappings return mappings set globally ggplot. passed single layer plot, behavior get_mappings depend value local_only. local_only = TRUE, get_mappings return mappings defined locally layer. local_only = FALSE, get_mappings return combination global local methods used plot layer.

title: Get aesthetic mappings from a layer or plot — get_mappings
code: require(ggplot2) p <- ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +   geom_point(mapping = aes(color = class)) get_mappings(p) #> Aesthetic mapping:  #> * `x` -> `displ` #> * `y` -> `hwy` get_mappings(get_geom_layer(p, i = 1), local_only = FALSE) #> Aesthetic mapping:  #> * `x`      -> `displ` #> * `y`      -> `hwy` #> * `colour` -> `class`

text: Users can specify layer one 3 ways: order appearance . first layer appear plot (one drawn first, bottom) corresponds = 1. type stat stat. get_stat_layer return first layer uses stat combination stat . get_stat_layer return ith layer uses stat

title: Isolate a stat layer from a plot — get_stat_layer
code: require(ggplot2) p <- ggplot(data = diamonds, aes(price)) +   stat_bin(bins = 20, binwidth = 500)  get_stat_layer(p, i = 1) #> $layer #> geom_bar: na.rm = FALSE, orientation = NA #> stat_bin: binwidth = 500, bins = 20, center = NULL, boundary = NULL, breaks = NULL, closed = c("right", "left"), pad = FALSE, na.rm = FALSE, orientation = NA #> position_stack  #>  #> $global_data #> # A tibble: 53,940 × 10 #>    carat cut       color clarity depth table price     x     y     z #>    <dbl> <ord>     <ord> <ord>   <dbl> <dbl> <int> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #>  1  0.23 Ideal     E     SI2      61.5    55   326  3.95  3.98  2.43 #>  2  0.21 Premium   E     SI1      59.8    61   326  3.89  3.84  2.31 #>  3  0.23 Good      E     VS1      56.9    65   327  4.05  4.07  2.31 #>  4  0.29 Premium   I     VS2      62.4    58   334  4.2   4.23  2.63 #>  5  0.31 Good      J     SI2      63.3    58   335  4.34  4.35  2.75 #>  6  0.24 Very Good J     VVS2     62.8    57   336  3.94  3.96  2.48 #>  7  0.24 Very Good I     VVS1     62.3    57   336  3.95  3.98  2.47 #>  8  0.26 Very Good H     SI1      61.9    55   337  4.07  4.11  2.53 #>  9  0.22 Fair      E     VS2      65.1    61   337  3.87  3.78  2.49 #> 10  0.23 Very Good H     VS1      59.4    61   338  4     4.05  2.39 #> # … with 53,930 more rows #>  #> $global_mapping #> Aesthetic mapping:  #> * `x` -> `price` #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "layer_to_check" get_stat_layer(p, stat = "bin") #> $layer #> geom_bar: na.rm = FALSE, orientation = NA #> stat_bin: binwidth = 500, bins = 20, center = NULL, boundary = NULL, breaks = NULL, closed = c("right", "left"), pad = FALSE, na.rm = FALSE, orientation = NA #> position_stack  #>  #> $global_data #> # A tibble: 53,940 × 10 #>    carat cut       color clarity depth table price     x     y     z #>    <dbl> <ord>     <ord> <ord>   <dbl> <dbl> <int> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #>  1  0.23 Ideal     E     SI2      61.5    55   326  3.95  3.98  2.43 #>  2  0.21 Premium   E     SI1      59.8    61   326  3.89  3.84  2.31 #>  3  0.23 Good      E     VS1      56.9    65   327  4.05  4.07  2.31 #>  4  0.29 Premium   I     VS2      62.4    58   334  4.2   4.23  2.63 #>  5  0.31 Good      J     SI2      63.3    58   335  4.34  4.35  2.75 #>  6  0.24 Very Good J     VVS2     62.8    57   336  3.94  3.96  2.48 #>  7  0.24 Very Good I     VVS1     62.3    57   336  3.95  3.98  2.47 #>  8  0.26 Very Good H     SI1      61.9    55   337  4.07  4.11  2.53 #>  9  0.22 Fair      E     VS2      65.1    61   337  3.87  3.78  2.49 #> 10  0.23 Very Good H     VS1      59.4    61   338  4     4.05  2.39 #> # … with 53,930 more rows #>  #> $global_mapping #> Aesthetic mapping:  #> * `x` -> `price` #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "layer_to_check"

what: List the stats used by a plot — get_stats
title: List the stats used by a plot — get_stats
text: get_stats returns vector stats names, written character strings, describes stats order used plot.

title: List the stats used by a plot — get_stats
code: get_stats(p)

title: List the stats used by a plot — get_stats
text: p ggplot object

title: List the stats used by a plot — get_stats
text: vector character strings. element corresponds suffix ggplot2 stat_ function, e.g. c("identity", "smooth").

title: List the stats used by a plot — get_stats
code: require(ggplot2) p <- ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +   geom_point(mapping = aes(color = class)) +   geom_smooth() get_stats(p) #> [1] "identity" "smooth"

what: ggcheck: Inspect 'ggplot2' Plots for Automated Grading in Learning Exercises — ggcheck-package
title: ggcheck: Inspect 'ggplot2' Plots for Automated Grading in Learning Exercises — ggcheck-package
text: 'ggcheck' provides functions inspect 'ggplot2' objects make easier teachers check student plots meet expectations. Designed primarily automated grading via 'gradethis' interactive 'learnr' tutorials.

title: ggcheck: Inspect 'ggplot2' Plots for Automated Grading in Learning Exercises — ggcheck-package
text: Maintainer: Garrick Aden-Buie garrick@rstudio.com (ORCID) Authors: Garrett Grolemund garrett@rstudio.com (ORCID) [conceptor] Nischal Shrestha nsrocker92@gmail.com (ORCID) contributors: Alexander Rossell Hayes alex.rossellhayes@rstudio.com (ORCID) [contributor] Sara Altman sara.altman@rstudio.com (ORCID) [contributor] RStudio, PBC [copyright holder, funder]

title: Are aesthetic mapping specifications
text: ggplot2 package uses quosures record aesthetic mappings. record mapping described well environment mapping described. result, difficult compare mappings created students one environment mappings created fly graders another environment. identical_aes facilitates comparison ignoring environments associated aesthetic mapping specification. two specifications contain identical expressions, e.g. x = displ, etc., identical_aes returns TRUE.

title: Are aesthetic mapping specifications
code: identical_aes(a1, a2)

title: Are aesthetic mapping specifications
text: a1 output aes, perhaps extracted ggplot object. a2 output aes, perhaps extracted ggplot object.

title: Are aesthetic mapping specifications
text: TRUE FALSE

what: Check if an object is a ggplot — is_ggplot
title: Check if an object is a ggplot — is_ggplot
text: is_ggplot() tests object ggplot. stop_if_not_ggplot() signals error object ggplot. fail_if_not_ggplot() returns failing grade object ggplot.

title: Check if an object is a ggplot — is_ggplot
code: is_ggplot(p)  stop_if_not_ggplot(p, message = getOption("ggcheck.error"))  fail_if_not_ggplot(   p = .result,   message = getOption("ggcheck.fail"),   env = parent.frame() )

title: Check if an object is a ggplot — is_ggplot
text: p object message message displayed p ggplot object. env Environment find .result. users ggcheck need use argument.

title: Check if an object is a ggplot — is_ggplot
text: is_ggplot() returns TRUE p ggplotobject; otherwise returns FALSE. stop_if_not_ggplot() returns error p ggplot object; invisibly returns NULL. fail_if_not_ggplot() returns failing grade p ggplot object; invisibly returns NULL.

title: Check if an object is a ggplot — is_ggplot
code: require(ggplot2)  p_valid <- ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +   geom_point() is_ggplot(p_valid) #> [1] TRUE stop_if_not_ggplot(p_valid) fail_if_not_ggplot(p_valid)  p_invalid <- geom_point() is_ggplot(p_invalid) #> [1] FALSE if (FALSE) { stop_if_not_ggplot(p_invalid) } fail_if_not_ggplot(p_valid)

what: Which data set does the ith layer use? — ith_data
title: Which data set does the ith layer use? — ith_data

title: Which data set does the ith layer use? — ith_data
code: ith_data(p, i, local_only = FALSE)

title: Which data set does the ith layer use? — ith_data
text: p ggplot object layer extracted ggplot object get_geom_layer. numerical index corresponds first layer plot (1), second layer (2), . local_only TRUE FALSE. See details.

title: Which data set does the ith layer use? — ith_data
text: data frame. data set found, ith_data returns NULL.

title: Which data set does the ith layer use? — ith_data
text: local_only = TRUE, ith_data returns data set, , defined locally function created ith layer. local_only = FALSE, ith_data returns data used ith layer, whether data defined globally ggplot locally. Functions use ith_ prefix designed eliminate need call get_geom_layer check specific layer plot, e.g. p %>% get_geom_layer(geom = "point") %>% get_data().

title: Which data set does the ith layer use? — ith_data
code: require(ggplot2) d2 <- head(mpg) p <- ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +   geom_point(data = d2, color = "red") +   geom_point() ith_data(p, i = 1) #> # A tibble: 6 × 11 #>   manufacturer model displ  year   cyl trans drv     cty   hwy fl    class #>   <chr>        <chr> <dbl> <int> <int> <chr> <chr> <int> <int> <chr> <chr> #> 1 audi         a4      1.8  1999     4 auto… f        18    29 p     comp… #> 2 audi         a4      1.8  1999     4 manu… f        21    29 p     comp… #> 3 audi         a4      2    2008     4 manu… f        20    31 p     comp… #> 4 audi         a4      2    2008     4 auto… f        21    30 p     comp… #> 5 audi         a4      2.8  1999     6 auto… f        16    26 p     comp… #> 6 audi         a4      2.8  1999     6 manu… f        18    26 p     comp…

title: Does the ith layer use the correct data set? — ith_data_is
text: Functions use ith_ prefix designed eliminate need call get_geom_layer check specific layer plot, e.g. p %>% get_geom_layer(geom = "point") %>% uses_data(mpg). local_only = TRUE, ith_data_is check data set, , defined locally function created ith layer. local_only = FALSE, ith_data_is check data used ith layer, whether data defined globally ggplot locally.

title: Does the ith layer use the correct data set? — ith_data_is
code: require(ggplot2) d2 <- head(mpg) p <- ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +   geom_point(data = d2, color = "red") +   geom_point() ith_data_is(p, data = head(mpg), i = 1) #> [1] TRUE

text: p ggplot object numerical index corresponds first layer plot (1), second layer (2), .

title: Which geom/stat combination is used in the ith layer? — ith_geom_stat
text: list lists GEOM STAT strings, corresponding suffix ggplot2 geom_ function (e.g. "point"),  stat_ function (e.g. "identity"). e.g. list(list(GEOM = "point", STAT = "identity"))

title: Which geom/stat combination is used in the ith layer? — ith_geom_stat
code: require(ggplot2) p <- ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +   geom_point(mapping = aes(color = class)) +   geom_smooth() ith_geom_stat(p, i = 2) #> $GEOM #> [1] "smooth" #>  #> $STAT #> [1] "smooth" #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "GEOM_STAT"

title: Return the aesthetic mappings used by the ith layer — ith_mappings
text: p ggplot object layer extracted ggplot object get_geom_layer get_stat_layer. numerical index corresponds first layer plot (1), second layer (2), . ith_mappings_use check aesthetics used ith layer. local_only TRUE, ith_mappings_use check mappings defined locally layer presence mappings. FALSE, ith_mappings_use check mappings combination global local methods used plot layer.

title: Return the aesthetic mappings used by the ith layer — ith_mappings
text: list class uneval, returned aesComponents list either quosures constants.

title: Return the aesthetic mappings used by the ith layer — ith_mappings
text: Functions use ith_ prefix designed eliminate need call get_layer check specific layer plot, e.g. p %>% get_geom_layer(geom = "point") %>% get_mappings().

title: Return the aesthetic mappings used by the ith layer — ith_mappings
code: require(ggplot2) p <- ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +   geom_point(mapping = aes(color = class)) +   geom_smooth() ith_mappings(p, i = 1, local_only = FALSE) #> Aesthetic mapping:  #> * `x`      -> `displ` #> * `y`      -> `hwy` #> * `colour` -> `class` ith_mappings(p, i = 1, local_only = TRUE) #> Aesthetic mapping:  #> * `colour` -> `class` ith_mappings(p, i = 2, local_only = FALSE) #> Aesthetic mapping:  #> * `x` -> `displ` #> * `y` -> `hwy`

title: Does the ith layer use one or more aesthetic mappings? — ith_mappings_use

title: Does the ith layer use one or more aesthetic mappings? — ith_mappings_use
code: require(ggplot2) p <- ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +   geom_point(mapping = aes(color = class)) +   geom_smooth() ith_mappings_use(p, i = 1, aes(x = displ), local_only = FALSE) #> [1] TRUE ith_mappings_use(p, i = 1, aes(x = displ), local_only = TRUE) #> [1] FALSE ith_mappings_use(p, i = 2, aes(x = displ, y = hwy), local_only = FALSE) #> [1] TRUE

title: Does a plot use one or more aesthetics? — uses_aesthetics
text: p ggplot object layer extracted ggplot object get_geom_layer get_stat_layer.. aesthetics character vector variables check , e.g. "x" c("x") local_only TRUE FALSE. uses_aesthetics return mappings defined locally layer? exact TRUE, variables need mapped exactly

title: Does a plot use one or more aesthetics? — uses_aesthetics
text: logical value.

title: Does a plot use one or more aesthetics? — uses_aesthetics
text: default, uses_aesthetics requires one aesthetics need used. Set exact TRUE check variables matched exactly.

title: Does a plot use one or more aesthetics? — uses_aesthetics
code: require(ggplot2) p <- ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +   geom_point(mapping = aes(color = class)) uses_aesthetics(p, "x") #> [1] TRUE uses_aesthetics(p, c("x", "y")) #> [1] TRUE uses_aesthetics(get_geom_layer(p, "point"), c("x", "y", "color"), local_only = TRUE) #> [1] TRUE uses_aesthetics(get_geom_layer(p, "point"), c("x", "y"), local_only = FALSE) #> [1] TRUE

text: TRUE FALSE

title: Does a plot use the correct coordinate system? — uses_coordinate_system
code: require(ggplot2) p <- ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +   geom_point(mapping = aes(color = class)) +   geom_smooth() +   coord_polar() uses_coordinate_system(p, coordinates = "polar") #> [1] TRUE

title: Does a plot or layer use the correct data set? — uses_data
code: require(ggplot2) d2 <- head(mpg) p <- ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +   geom_point(data = d2, color = "red") +   geom_point() uses_data(p, mpg) #> [1] TRUE uses_data(get_geom_layer(p, i = 1), data = head(mpg)) #> [1] TRUE

title: Does a layer use one of more specific parameters? — uses_geom_params
text: p ggplot object geom character string found suffix ggplot2 geom function, e.g. "point". ... <dynamic-dots> Named values character strings. Unnamed arguments check whether value set parameter. Named arguments check whether parameter name matching value. argument name matching ggplot layer parameter. Values may passed arguments list elements. params named list geom stat parameter values, e.g. list(outlier.alpha = 0.01). list combined inputs ... numerical index, e.g. 1.

title: Does a layer use one of more specific parameters? — uses_geom_params
text: named logical vector length number inputs ....

title: Does a layer use one of more specific parameters? — uses_geom_params
text: specify specific geom layer, either specify using position using index using combination geom function suffix name check ith layer uses geom. params argument accepts list contains geom, stat, aes parameters. offers flexibility certain situations setting parameter geom_ function actually setting stat parameter aes parameter. example, geom_histogram(binwidth = 500), binwidth stat parameter, geom_histogram(fill = "blue"), fill aes parameter. uses_geom_params take account check geom, stat, aes parameters. Note uses_geom_params() can detect aes parameters, aes mappings. Parameters set static values directly within layer (e.g. geom_point(color = "blue")), mappings associate variables data plot aesthetics using aes() (e.g. geom_point(aes(color = class))).

title: Does a layer use one of more specific parameters? — uses_geom_params
code: require(ggplot2)  p <- ggplot(data = diamonds, aes(x = cut, y = price)) +   geom_boxplot(varwidth = TRUE, outlier.alpha = 0.01, fill = "blue")  uses_geom_params(   p, "boxplot", list(varwidth = TRUE, outlier.alpha = 0.01, fill = "blue") ) #>      varwidth outlier.alpha          fill  #>          TRUE          TRUE          TRUE   uses_geom_params(   p, "boxplot", varwidth = TRUE, outlier.alpha = 0.01, fill = "blue" ) #>      varwidth outlier.alpha          fill  #>          TRUE          TRUE          TRUE   # Unnamed arguments check that a parameter is set to any value uses_geom_params(p, "boxplot", "fill") #> fill  #> TRUE

what: Does a plot use one or more geoms? — uses_geoms
title: Does a plot use one or more geoms? — uses_geoms
text: use_geoms tests whether plot uses one geoms created using geom. checking layer created using stat function, please use uses_stats instead.

title: Does a plot use one or more geoms? — uses_geoms
code: uses_geoms(p, geoms, stats = NULL, exact = TRUE)

title: Does a plot use one or more geoms? — uses_geoms
text: p ggplot object geoms vector character strings. element correspond suffix ggplot2 geom_ function, e.g. c("point",   "line", "smooth"). stats character vector optionally check stats corresponding geoms e.g. c("identity", "smooth") checking c("point", "smooth") exact boolean indicate whether use exact matching

title: Does a plot use one or more geoms? — uses_geoms
text: TRUE FALSE

title: Does a plot use one or more geoms? — uses_geoms
text: default, plot must exact geoms geom/stat combinations order. However, exact set FALSE, plot geoms geom/stat combinations exact.

title: Does a plot use one or more geoms? — uses_geoms
code: require(ggplot2) p <- ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +   geom_point(mapping = aes(color = class)) +   geom_smooth() uses_geoms(p, geoms = "point") #> [1] FALSE uses_geoms(p, geoms = c("point", "smooth"), exact = TRUE) #> [1] TRUE uses_geoms(p, geoms = c("point", "smooth"), stats = c("identity", "smooth")) #> [1] TRUE

what: Does a plot use one or more labels? — uses_labels
title: Does a plot use one or more labels? — uses_labels
text: uses_labels() tests whether plot uses one labels.

title: Does a plot use one or more labels? — uses_labels
code: uses_labels(p, ...)

title: Does a plot use one or more labels? — uses_labels
text: p ggplot object ... <dynamic-dots> Character strings. Unnamed arguments check whether label exists aesthetic. Named arguments check whether aesthetic name label matching value. argument matching ggplot aesthetic label. Strings may input individual arguments list elements.

title: Does a plot use one or more labels? — uses_labels
text: named logical vector length number inputs ....

title: Does a plot use one or more labels? — uses_labels
text: Note uses_labels() match NULL label explicitly set NULL requested aesthetic present plot.

title: Does a plot use one or more labels? — uses_labels
code: require(ggplot2)  p <- ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +   geom_point(mapping = aes(color = class, shape = drv)) +   geom_smooth() +   labs(title = "My plot", x = "Weight", y = "MPG", color = NULL)  # Unnamed arguments check if a label is set for the given aesthetic uses_labels(p, "title", "subtitle", "x", "y") #>    title subtitle        x        y  #>     TRUE    FALSE     TRUE     TRUE   # The check will return TRUE for labels set to NULL uses_labels(p, "color") #> color  #>  TRUE   # The check will return TRUE for aesthetics with default labels uses_labels(p, "shape") #> shape  #>  TRUE   # Named arguments check if the label matches an expected value uses_labels(p, x = "Weight") #>    x  #> TRUE  uses_labels(p, x = "Weight", y = "MPG", color = NULL) #>     x     y color  #>  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE   # You can check for default labels with default_label() uses_labels(p, shape = default_label(), x = default_label()) #> shape     x  #>  TRUE FALSE   # The colo(u)r aesthetic can be matched with or without a u uses_labels(p, color = NULL) #> color  #>  TRUE  uses_labels(p, colour = NULL) #> colour  #>   TRUE   # Inputs can be passed from a list, with or without the !!! operator label_list <- list(x = "Weight", y = "MPG", color = NULL) uses_labels(p, label_list) #>     x     y color  #>  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  uses_labels(p, !!!label_list) #>     x     y color  #>  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE

what: Does a plot or layer use one or more mappings? — uses_mappings
title: Does a plot or layer use one or more mappings? — uses_mappings
text: uses_mappings checks whether student used one mappings plot. default, uses_mappings ignores whether student also supplied additional mappings. Use uses_extra_mappings check . exact TRUE, mappings match exactly.

title: Does a plot or layer use one or more mappings? — uses_mappings
code: uses_mappings(p, mappings, local_only = FALSE, exact = FALSE)

title: Does a plot or layer use one or more mappings? — uses_mappings
text: p ggplot object layer extracted ggplot object get_geom_layer get_stat_layer. mappings One aesthetic mappings created aes. local_only TRUE, uses_mappings check mappings defined locally layer presence mappings. FALSE, uses_mappings check mappings combination global local methods used plot layer. exact TRUE, mappings need mapped exactly

title: Does a plot or layer use one or more mappings? — uses_mappings
text: logical value.

title: Does a plot or layer use one or more mappings? — uses_mappings
code: require(ggplot2) p <- ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +   geom_point(mapping = aes(color = class)) uses_mappings(p, aes(x = displ)) #> [1] TRUE uses_mappings(get_geom_layer(p, i = 1), aes(x = displ, color = class), local_only = FALSE) #> [1] TRUE uses_mappings(get_geom_layer(p, i = 1), aes(x = displ, color = class), local_only = TRUE) #> [1] FALSE uses_mappings(p, aes(x = displ, y = hwy), exact = TRUE) #> [1] TRUE

what: Does a layer use a specific stat parameter? — uses_stat_param
title: Does a layer use a specific stat parameter? — uses_stat_param
text: uses_stat_param mirror function uses_geom_param instead checking plot's geom layer, checks plot's stat layer uses specific stat parameter.

title: Does a layer use a specific stat parameter? — uses_stat_param
code: uses_stat_param(p, stat, params, i = NULL)

title: Does a layer use a specific stat parameter? — uses_stat_param
text: p ggplot object stat character string found suffix ggplot2 stat function, e.g. "bin". params named list stat geom parameter values, e.g. list(bins = 200) numerical index, e.g. 1.

title: Does a layer use a specific stat parameter? — uses_stat_param
text: boolean

title: Does a layer use a specific stat parameter? — uses_stat_param
text: specify specific stat layer, either specify using position using index using combination stat function suffix name check ith layer uses stat.

title: Does a layer use a specific stat parameter? — uses_stat_param
code: require(ggplot2) p <- ggplot(diamonds, aes(carat)) +   stat_bin(bins = 200) uses_stat_param(p, stat = "bin", params = list(bins = 200)) #> [1] TRUE

what: Does a plot use one or more stats? — uses_stats
title: Does a plot use one or more stats? — uses_stats
text: uses_stats tests whether plot uses one stats layers.

title: Does a plot use one or more stats? — uses_stats
code: uses_stats(p, stats, geoms = NULL, exact = TRUE)

title: Does a plot use one or more stats? — uses_stats
text: p ggplot object stats vector character strings. element correspond suffix ggplot2 stat_ function, e.g. c("identity", "smooth"). geoms character vector optionally check geoms corresponding stats e.g. c("point", "smooth") checking c("identity", "smooth") exact TRUE, use exact matching

title: Does a plot use one or more stats? — uses_stats
text: TRUE FALSE

title: Does a plot use one or more stats? — uses_stats
text: default, plot must exact stats geom/stat combinations order. However, exact set FALSE, plot stats geom/stat combinations exact.

title: Does a plot use one or more stats? — uses_stats
code: require(ggplot2) p <- ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +   geom_point(mapping = aes(color = class)) +   geom_smooth() uses_stats(p, stats = "smooth") #> [1] FALSE uses_stats(p, stats = c("identity", "smooth"), exact = TRUE) #> [1] TRUE uses_stats(p, c("smooth", "identity"), geoms = c("smooth", "point")) #> [1] FALSE

title: ggcheck 0.0.2 (2021-12-22)
text: get_labels() lists (subset ) labels plot uses_labels() checks labels match expected values Added fail_if_not_ggplot() use grading code check submitted result ggplot, powered lower-level testing function is_ggplot() (#29).

title: ggcheck 0.0.2 (2021-12-22)
text: Improve handling ... uses_labels() (#26) Unnamed arguments uses_labels() check label set (#27) Check aes params uses_geom_param() (#28)

title: ggcheck 0.0.1 (2021-10-22)
text: Initial release ggcheck
